title: Does the home buyer ever get to meet the seller? - Quora

response.answer_text: My husband and I have bought three houses, and sold two (we're still living in house #3, although it's currently on the market). My husband met the sellers of our first house at the walk-through, which happens just before the actual closing, while I stayed at home with the new baby. We moved to a different town, and were living there when we sold that house, so we never met the buyers. For our second house, we met the sellers numerous times because it was a new build, and they were the builders. (We ended up becoming good friends with one of them.) When we sold that house, I am sorry to say that the buyer was an obnoxious, pushy jerk, and I made a point of avoiding any and all contact with him. For the house we are now in, we ended up meeting the sellers after we had a contract (but pre-closing). We went to dinner with them once, and exchanged Christmas cards for a few years afterward. That said, I think our last two experiences with the sellers were unusual, at least where we live. People in our area tend to have outsized egos, and from experience I prefer having our realtor serve as a buffer between us and any potential buyers during this process. I personally think an arm's length transaction, at least during the negotiations process, is the best way to go. During the negotiations process, you get a good sense for the type of person you're dealing with on the other side, even if you don't see them in person. (And you get a lot of feedback from your Realtor, too.) Let's just say that there have been times that buffer has been very, very helpful. So, the short answer is: it depends.

It is entirely possible that the buyer and seller may never meet. For example, the buyer or seller may simply not be in town, in which case they will typically give their real estate attorney a power of attorney to execute contracts on their behalf. In NYC today, the closing process still requires an in-person “closing” meeting where all parties meet and physically sign documents (e-signatures are not valid for NYC property closings as of this writing). As a result, most home buyers and sellers in NYC will physically meet at least once at the closing. If a seller is selling their own home in NYC “For Sale By Owner,” or FSBO, then the seller will typically meet the home buyer during an open house or private showing. In NYC, it’s required to have a real estate attorney for the closing process since the purchase contract is customizable and more complex than the standard forms used elsewhere in the United States. Make sure you fully understand closing costs first: Closing Costs in NYC - What Buyers and Sellers Pay in NYC Learn how the closing process works in NYC: How the NYC FSBO closing process works for home sellers

There are no fixed rules for or against it. Often times the seller could be at home when the buyers are first viewing and they would meet. Some buyers like to accompany the inspectors and some sellers prefer to be home during the inspection, and so the parties could meet. Usually at the closing, it is more convenient to have both parties present. Having both parties meet can have its positive and negative repercussions though. At a closing I once had, the seller mentioned how happy she and her late husband of 54 years marriage had in the house. When she mentioned that the husband loved the place so much that he refused to move out and eventually died in the master suite, my buyer nearly cancelled the closing. She was convinced by us to close, but only reluctantly, and swore that she would not be sleeping in the room. A few months later I visited her and she was buying furnishings for the room and deciding to sleep there.

Whether or not the buyers meet the sellers is usually dependent on whether they chose to close their transaction at the same place and time. It doesn’t have to happen that way but it could if they use the same attorney or title company. There’s nothing wrong with the parties meeting at closing….it’s just signatures and handing over keys at that point. Personally, I’ve never met the buyers of the homes I’ve sold because I’ve already moved out of state and everything is handled electronically.

In some markets, the buyer and seller close together. So, yes they meet then. More often than not, the buyers and sellers do better for themselves if they never meet. Personalities get in the way of a sale/purchase far too often. Also, if they do get along, they get chatty and start agreeing to do things that aren’t in writing or specific. This leads to problems. It does happen that the real estate agents’ personality is a problem. Not as often, but there are bad agents out there. I’d like to note that there are also bad lawyers, bad doctors, bad neighbors…bad can come in any industry. I hope you’ve found this helpful.

It’s possible to meet the seller, but it doesn’t often turn out to be a great experience. The seller is looking for the highest possible price, while the buyer is looking for the opposite. When the buyer sees anything they do not like about the property, it annoys the seller to hear it. The buyer often thinks the seller is unreasonable and vice versa. Having agents intervene and smooth the path really does make for a better transaction for all.

Why? If you have questions, ask the broker. Sometimes you won’t get the answer; either way. If the seller’s out of state, you won’t. Sure, if I had a chance to video chat - with the seller my question would be,’What’s the neighbor like?’ But he’s probably lie anyway. If they’re using a broker/atty/rep no requirement to meet you.

It’s usually a bad idea. Both parties are friendly and over share information that comes back to hurt them, usually while negotiating repairs. I’ve seen buyers lose $10–25k because we knew there were no circumstances where they would walk away from the house over that amount of money. Conversely there have been sellers that had to sell no matter what so we came after the credits extremely hard. I tell clients to imagine $100 bills flying out of their mouth if they talk to the agent or buyer/seller on the other side,

I have always met potential buyers at the property, to give them the ‘nickel’ tour and let them know the features I’ve installed. Most realtors don’t like this, because they feel it challenges their authority and control.
